title: You are a patient advocate tasked with drafting a public health notice to educate the community about breast cancer risk factors, screening, and the importance of early detection. Your notice should reference clinical evidence and recommended practices.
content:
问题：You are a patient advocate tasked with drafting a public health notice to educate the community about breast cancer risk factors, screening, and the importance of early detection. Your notice should reference clinical evidence and recommended practices.
答案：Public Health Notice: Protect Yourself—Know the Facts About Breast Cancer

Breast cancer is a carcinoma that begins in the cells of the breast and is one of the most common cancers affecting individuals assigned female at birth. Key risk factors include a family history of breast cancer, inherited BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations, and certain hormonal or reproductive factors. Clinical evidence shows that regular screening mammograms are essential for early detection, even in people without symptoms, and can significantly improve treatment outcomes and survival rates. Common warning signs of breast cancer include a new breast lump, persistent pain, nipple discharge, or changes in the skin such as redness, swelling, or peau d’orange (skin thickening and dimpling). If you notice any of these symptoms, contact your healthcare provider promptly. Early detection through recommended screenings and awareness of personal risk factors are critical steps in reducing the impact of breast cancer. We urge all eligible individuals to follow current screening guidelines and to discuss their personal and family history with their healthcare provider to determine the best screening plan.

Issued by: Community Health Board
医学证据：Breast cancer is a carcinoma that starts in the cells of the breast.; Breast cancer primarily affects individuals assigned female at birth.; A family history of breast cancer increases risk.; BRCA1/2 mutations increase the risk of breast cancer.; Regular screening mammograms are crucial for early detection.; Early detection is important even in people without symptoms.; Symptoms of breast cancer include breast lumps, pain, nipple discharge, and skin changes.; Skin changes may include redness or swelling.; Consulting a healthcare provider promptly is important if symptoms are experienced.; Early-stage breast cancer is more treatable and has better outcomes.; Eligible individuals are encouraged to undergo recommended screenings.; Discussing personal risk factors with a doctor is important.

title: Transform the clinical facts on metastatic breast cancer (MBC) into a structured SOAP (Subjective, Objective, Assessment, Plan) progress note for a follow-up visit. Include relevant symptoms, diagnostics, biomarkers, and ongoing management.
content:
问题：Transform the clinical facts on metastatic breast cancer (MBC) into a structured SOAP (Subjective, Objective, Assessment, Plan) progress note for a follow-up visit. Include relevant symptoms, diagnostics, biomarkers, and ongoing management.
答案：SOAP Progress Note

Subjective: The patient reports ongoing bone pain and intermittent shortness of breath, which are consistent with known sites of metastatic disease. There are no new neurological symptoms (such as headache, weakness, or sensory changes) and no signs of liver dysfunction (such as jaundice or abdominal pain). The patient denies other new symptoms.

Objective: Recent PET scan demonstrates confirmed metastases to the bone and lung. Blood tests, including liver and renal function, are within normal limits. Biopsy of metastatic lesions confirms the diagnosis of metastatic breast cancer. Biomarker analysis shows the tumor is estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive, and HER2 negative. The patient’s performance status remains stable, with no decline in daily functioning.

Assessment: Stage IV (metastatic) breast cancer with documented bone and pulmonary involvement. The disease is hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR+) and HER2-negative, which guides systemic therapy choices. No evidence of new organ involvement or acute complications at this time.

Plan: Continue current systemic therapy regimen, consisting of endocrine therapy in combination with a CDK4/6 inhibitor, appropriate for hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative metastatic breast cancer. Continue bone-directed therapy with bisphosphonates to reduce skeletal-related events. Schedule regular imaging and physical examinations to monitor for disease progression or new metastases. Provide supportive care for symptom management, including pain control and addressing shortness of breath as needed. Discuss ongoing eligibility for targeted therapies and consider clinical trial options if appropriate. Maintain communication with the primary care physician and multidisciplinary care team.

title: Assume the role of a genetic counselor. Prepare a summary for a patient newly found to have a BRCA1 mutation, explaining the implications for breast cancer risk, recommended surveillance, and potential preventive strategies.
content:
问题：Assume the role of a genetic counselor. Prepare a summary for a patient newly found to have a BRCA1 mutation, explaining the implications for breast cancer risk, recommended surveillance, and potential preventive strategies.
答案：Genetic Counseling Summary:

You have tested positive for a BRCA1 mutation, which significantly increases your risk of developing breast cancer. Having a BRCA1 mutation is a strong risk factor and may also impact your family members’ risk. We recommend enhanced surveillance, including annual mammograms and breast MRI starting at an earlier age. Preventive strategies may include risk-reducing medications or prophylactic surgery (such as bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy). It is important to discuss these options with your oncology and surgical teams. Family members may also wish to consider genetic testing. Ongoing follow-up and support resources are available to you.
